awd_titl_txt: The Nature of Brain Networks in Cognitive Neuroimaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to clarify conceptual challenges in the burgeoning field of network neuroimaging. Network neuroscience uses mathematical tools from graph theory to understand the brain, its relationship to the mind, and the neural basis of neurological and psychiatric illnesses. However, the highly abstract nature of network analysis has produced deep methodological and conceptual disagreements regarding what exactly network methods reveal about the brain and its functions. This project aims to clearly articulate these disagreements and to use tools from philosophy of science to develop the conceptual foundations necessary to resolve them. The project’s findings will be disseminated through both scholarly and public channels and will be of interest to practicing network neuroimagers, philosophers of science, clinical neuroscientists, and members of the general public interested in brain function and malfunction.

The central points of disagreement among practicing network neuroscientists concern the extent to which the structures revealed in network neuroimaging are biologically meaningful, as opposed to merely instrumental mathematical abstractions, and relatedly, whether and to what extent functions can be attributed to these networks. The research team will analyze and build on survey results among practicing network neuroscientists that unveil these conceptual disagreements. The project then seeks to use tools from philosophy of science to develop a conceptual framework with two central aims: To show how different modeling commitments affect the extent to which brain networks can be interpreted as biologically real or meaningful, and to articulate the appropriate conditions under which functions can be attributed to brain networks. The results of this project will provide insight into both the strengths and limitations of network methods when employed for different research purposes in neuroscience. These insights will help researchers overcome hurdles that currently threaten progress in the field, will open new avenues of research in philosophy of science, and will facilitate clearer interpretations of results in this cutting-edge area of neuroscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project had two main objectives, one involving research and a second one involving training. The research goal was to demonstrate, through several academic papers, how the conceptual tools of philosophy could be helpful to cognitive neuroscientists analyzing neuroimaging data with topological and network models.  The fruit of this research is exemplified in the production of four research papers—one published, one under review, and two more in production—as well as a symposium on Causality and Explanation in Network Science, that will take place at the Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association in November, 2024. In these papers, we discuss, among other things, the perils of reifying network models of brain imaging data as if they were biologically identifiable structures that evolved for a particular function. Likewise, we discuss how to leverage network models to try to frame the notion of “cognitive system” in less modular and more dynamical ways. We also discuss the use of computational modeling in providing the tools for successful causal explanations in network science, as well as the role of network models in other kinds of neuroscientific explanation. 

The second aim pertained to post-doctoral training. During the two years of this grant, a post-doctoral researcher with a strong background in philosophy of neuroscience joined our lab. He was the co-author of all of the papers and also the co-organizer of the symposium mentioned above. In addition to receiving cross-disciplinary training and strengthening their research portfolio, this post-doctoral position hope to set him in a path to secure a tenure-track position. I am happy to report that he secured such a position, and now is a newly appointed assistant professor at a top research university. Thanks to this grant, his research trajectory continued with much success.
